hedline.hl1: Analyzing the Id Behind the Wheel

abstract.p: Christopher Wanjek letter comments on July 17 article on research by Detroit automakers to figure out personality profiles of those who purchase minivans versus those who buy sport utility vehicles; drawing (S)

block.p: ''Was Freud a Minivan or S.U.V. Kind of Guy?'' (front page, July 17) presents an intriguing psychological profile of the type of person who drives a minivan and the type of person who drives a sport utility vehicle.

There is one similarity, however, between the two types of otherwise disparate consumers that is not mentioned: they are both socially irresponsible. Both types of vehicles squander too much gasoline and take up too much of the road. Few of us really need a car this big.

''Was Freud a Minivan or S.U.V. Kind of Guy?'' (front page, July 17) presents an intriguing psychological profile of the type of person who drives a minivan and the type of person who drives a sport utility vehicle.

There is one similarity, however, between the two types of otherwise disparate consumers that is not mentioned: they are both socially irresponsible. Both types of vehicles squander too much gasoline and take up too much of the road. Few of us really need a car this big.

The choices in your headline imply that Freud would have been consumed by a status symbol. If Freud were alive, I think he'd more likely drive a tiny automobile and quip, ''Sometimes a car is just a car.''
CHRISTOPHER WANJEK Takoma Park, Md., July 17, 2000
